title: Can air cleaning devices that use bipolar ionization, including portable air cleaners and in-duct air cleaners used in HVAC systems, protect me from COVID-19? | US EPA

last_post.content:
So let's say that we had a functioning government that was going to publish the right things to do to make your home a safe(r) place to invite guests into. Have they published homeowner guides on how to make a home well-prepared to combat COVID-19 and successive respiratory viruses?

My family's path for much of the last 3 years has been: No one comes inside. That has been changing now that all of us have been eligible and able to get the bivalent boosters. (My family includes immunocompromised people, people who really don't want to live the next 80 years with Long Covid, and infants/toddlers who cannot wear masks). Even still, we limit crowd sizes and always prefer outdoors or open windows.

But what about winter / bad weather? Can we never have house guests again?

What should we be doing? Corsi Rosenthal boxes strewn about common areas?

The EPA talks about fitting HVAC systems with Needlepoint Bipolar Ionization; these are available on Amazon for a few hundred dollars, but are they good? Can I install one myself, or do I need to convince a local HVAC place to order one? Do they know what they should be buying?:
https://www.epa.gov/coronavirus/can-air-cleaning-devices-use-bipolar-ionization-including-portable-air-cleaners-and

Is there a guide that is somewhere for residential "I want to spend money to make my house safer for us and our guests"? Pretty much everything is "businesses have (not) upgraded" but I don't have any idea how I would measure air changes per hour, etc. etc.

In today's parlance the TL;DR would read "feature selection is really important."

title: Furby 1998 source code : David Hampton, Wayne Schulz : Free Download, Borrow, and Streaming : Internet Archive

last_post.content:
The Furby source code is public and heavily commented. For example, it turns the microphone off when the motors are running.

Furby was the 1998 version of ChatGPT and tons of people thought it actually slowly learned English words. The NSA was alarmed. However it turned out the "learning" process was just on a timer and the "microphone" only triggers on loud sounds.
https://archive.org/details/furby-source
